properties.description: Not Applicable (no global hypothesis specified for this run)
Colonial Resistance to British Policies
Political Mobilization and Coordination among Colonies
Escalation of Tensions between Britain and Colonies
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs
British policy of salutary neglect (1651–1763)
Development of a unique American identity separate from British
French and Indian War
British defeat France and acquire territory east of Mississippi River
British Parliament imposes new taxes on colonies
Control of colonies' western lands turned over to British officials in Montreal
Grenville ministry issues Royal Proclamation of 1763, designating western territory as Indian Reserve closed to white settlement
Proclamation of 1763 angers settlers, fur traders, and land speculators
Parliament passes the Sugar Act, decreasing duties but increasing enforcement
Parliament passes the Stamp Act, imposing first direct taxes on colonies
Sons of Liberty form in response to Stamp Act
Sons of Liberty use public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence
British tax laws became unenforceable due to Sons of Liberty actions
Sons of Liberty burn records of the vice admiralty court in Boston
Sons of Liberty loot the home of chief justice Thomas Hutchinson in Boston
Stamp Act Congress convenes with delegates from nine colonies
Stamp Act Congress adopts 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances'
Colonists organize a boycott on imports of all British merchandise
Parliament repeals the Stamp Act
Widespread celebrations in the colonies following Stamp Act repeal
Parliament insists on full power to make laws for colonies ('in all cases whatsoever') in Declaratory Act
British Parliament passes the Townshend Acts, placing duties on staple goods
Board of Customs established in Boston for stricter trade enforcement
Colonists organize new boycotts of British goods in response to Townshend Acts
Massachusetts Bay Colony Assembly issues a circular letter urging coordinated resistance
Governor dissolves Massachusetts Assembly for refusing to rescind circular letter
Riot breaks out in Boston over seizure of John Hancock's sloop 'Liberty'
Customs officials forced to flee Boston after Liberty riot
British deploy troops to Boston in response to unrest
Boston town meeting declares no obedience due to parliamentary laws and calls for a convention
Parliament reactivates Treason Act 1543, calling for trials in England
Threat of trial under Treason Act causes widespread outrage in colonies
British soldiers fire into a crowd, killing civilians in Boston
British soldiers involved in Boston Massacre are tried and acquitted
Widespread descriptions of Boston Massacre turn colonial sentiment against the British
Lord North ministry repeals most Townshend duties, except tea tax
American patriots burn British customs schooner HMS Gaspee
Private letters from Massachusetts Governor Thomas Hutchinson published
Contents of Hutchinson's letters used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Governor Hutchinson discredited in the eyes of the people
Colonial Assembly petitions for recall of Governor Hutchinson
Committees of Correspondence formed/expanded, linking Patriots across colonies
Committees of Correspondence provide framework for a rebel government
Committees enforce boycott of British products (after First Continental Congress)
Parliament passes the Tea Act, lowering price of taxed tea
Tea Act opposed by those resisting taxes and by smugglers
Demonstrators warn merchants not to bring in taxed tea
Special tea consignees forced by Americans to resign
Tea ships turned back in most colonies
Sons of Liberty activists dump tea into Boston Harbor
British government passes four Intolerable Acts in response to Boston Tea Party
Boston Port Act closes port until compensation paid for tea
Massachusetts Government Act alters charter and restricts town meetings
Administration of Justice Act orders British soldiers' trials in Britain
Quartering Act of 1774 allows housing troops in citizens' homes without permission
Intolerable Acts effectively end self-government in Massachusetts
Intolerable Acts expand and intensify the revolutionary cause
Massachusetts patriots issue the Suffolk Resolves
Alternative shadow government (Provincial Congress) formed in Massachusetts
Provincial Congress begins training militia outside British-occupied Boston
First Continental Congress convenes
First Continental Congress begins coordinating Patriot resistance through networks of committees
First Continental Congress calls for a boycott of all British goods
Battles of Lexington and Concord
American Revolutionary War launched
Second Continental Congress convenes
Second Continental Congress forms the Continental Army
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army
Washington and Continental Army surround Boston
British forced to withdraw from Boston by sea
Patriots in control in every colony
King George III proclaims Massachusetts in state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress debates Articles of Confederation
Second Continental Congress passes the Lee Resolution, affirming support for independence
Second Continental Congress unanimously adopts the Declaration of Independence
Revolutionary War continues for five more years
France enters the war supporting the colonial cause
Continental Army led by Washington achieves decisive victory in Siege of Yorktown, capturing British troops under Cornwallis
Collapse of King George III's control of Parliament
Consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms
British sign the Treaty of Paris, granting independence and territory
Independence of the United States of America from Great Britain
United States becomes the first constitutional republic founded on consent of governed and rule of law

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson
properties.role: Author of Declaration of Independence, Patriot leader

properties.description: 'Taxation without representation' violates the rights of Englishmen
Parliament is the supreme lawmaking authority throughout the Empire, entitled to levy any tax without colonial approval
The colonies are legally British corporations subordinate to the British Parliament
Colonists effectively enjoy 'virtual representation' in Parliament
The purpose of the Townshend Acts (specifically the tea tax) was to raise revenue, not regulate trade
Governor Hutchinson's letters reveal a systematic plot against American rights
The policy of salutary neglect caused Americans to become almost completely self-governing.
French entry into the war and support was decisive for the colonial cause of independence.
Colonists organize a boycott on imports of all British merchandise following the Stamp Act Congress.
Sons of Liberty use public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence, leading to tax laws becoming unenforceable.
Declaration of Rights and Grievances stating colonists were equal to other British citizens and taxation without representation violated rights.
James Otis maintained there was no one in Parliament responsible specifically to any colonial constituency.
Benjamin Franklin explaining to Parliament that colonies spent heavily in wars and further taxes were unjust and might bring rebellion.
New boycotts of British goods organized in response to Townshend Acts.
Massachusetts Assembly issuing a circular letter urging coordinated resistance.
Riot in Boston over the seizure of John Hancock's sloop 'Liberty'.
British deploying troops to Boston in response to unrest.
Widespread outrage caused by Parliament reactivating the Treason Act 1543.
British soldiers firing into a crowd, killing civilians in Boston.
American patriots burning the British customs schooner HMS Gaspee.
Published private letters from Governor Hutchinson claiming colonists could not enjoy all English liberties and calling for direct payment of officials.
Formation and expansion of Committees of Correspondence linking Patriots across colonies.
Opposition to the Tea Act by those resisting taxes and smugglers.
Tea consignees forced to resign and tea ships turned back in most colonies.
Sons of Liberty activists dumping £10,000 worth of tea into Boston Harbor.
British government passing the four Intolerable Acts (Boston Port, Mass Gov, Admin Justice, Quartering) in response to Boston Tea Party.
Massachusetts patriots issuing the Suffolk Resolves and forming the Provincial Congress.
Provincial Congress begins training militia.
First Continental Congress convenes as a vehicle for deliberation and collective action.
First Continental Congress calls for a boycott of all British goods, enforced by new local committees.
Battles of Lexington and Concord.
By March 1776, Patriots were in control in every colony.
King George III proclaims Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion.
Unanimous adoption of the Declaration of Independence.
Decisive victory by Washington and Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown, capturing British troops.
British signing the Treaty of Paris acknowledging independence and granting territory.
Colonists had become almost completely self-governing before the Revolution

properties.source_text_quote: "Americans had become almost completely self-governing" before the American Revolution, a practice that was consistent with the British monarchy's practice of salutary neglect.
The letters' contents were used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights, and discredited Hutchinson in the eyes of the people
during which France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause of independence
Congress emphasized their determination by organizing a boycott on imports of all British merchandise.
Sons of Liberty formed, and began using public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence to ensure that the British tax laws became unenforceable.
drew up a Declaration of Rights and Grievances stating that the colonists were equal to all other British citizens and that taxes passed without representation violated their rights as Englishmen
Americans such as James Otis maintained that there was no one in Parliament responsible specifically to any colonial constituency, so they were not "virtually represented" by anyone in Parliament.
explaining that the colonies had spent heavily in manpower, money, and blood defending the empire, and that further taxes to pay for those wars were unjust and might bring about a rebellion.
Colonists responded to the taxes by organizing new boycotts of British goods.
the Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter to the other colonies urging them to coordinate resistance.
a riot broke out in Boston in June 1768 over the seizure of the sloop Liberty
Customs officials were forced to flee, prompting the British to deploy troops to Boston.
the threat caused widespread outrage
British troops killed protesters in the Boston Massacre on March 5, 1770.
American patriots, including John Brown, burned a British warship... in what became known as the Gaspee Affair.

In 1773, private letters were published in which Massachusetts Governor Thomas Hutchinson claimed that the colonists could not enjoy all English liberties, and in which Lieutenant Governor Andrew Oliver called for the direct payment of colonial officials... The letters' contents were used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence, which linked Patriots in all 13 colonies and eventually provided the framework for a rebel government.
The act was opposed by those who resisted the taxes and also by smugglers who stood to lose business.
In most instances, the consignees were forced by the Americans to resign and the tea was turned back
On December 16, 1773, ... Sons of Liberty activists ... dumped chests of tea ... into Boston Harbor.
On December 16, 1773, ... Sons of Liberty activists ... dumped chests of tea ... into Boston Harbor.
The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts, further darkening colonial opinion towards England.
In response, Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves and formed an alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress
which began training militia outside British-occupied Boston.
In September 1774, the First Continental Congress convened, consisting of representatives from each colony, to serve as a vehicle for deliberation and collective action.
Congress called for a boycott beginning on December 1, 1774, of all British goods; it was enforced by new local committees authorized by the Congress.
The revolution culminated in the American Revolutionary War, which was launched on April 19, 1775, in the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
...leaving Patriots in control in every colony.
In August 1775, King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion.
...unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence the following year, which inspired, formalized, and escalated the war.

But in 1781, a decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown inspired King George III and the British to negotiate an end to colonial rule in the colonies and acknowledge their independence
...which was codified in the Treaty of Paris in 1783, leading to the establishment of the sovereign United States of America.
